Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Lattice Automation High Throughput DNA Cloning Solutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers are further developing solutions for high throughput cloning of DNA through synthetic biology. The project expands on data management, design constraint specification, DNA assembly design, and experimental protocol planning. These techniques each present algorithmic challenges as well as empirical laboratory challenges. The replacement of many manual processes with automated, high throughput techniques requires an interdisciplinary design team, a highly coordinated computational/experimental effort, and a rapid design-build-test cycle to validate the approach. This work may answer questions related to the predictive engineering of compositional DNA designs with minimal manual human intervention.

The results of this effort may impact the way that synthetic biology designs are conceived, designed, and physically created. The team's techniques will contribute to the rapid creation of new genetic material as well as broadly applicable design strategies that can be made available to the entire biological community. This work has the potential to seed an emerging bio-design automation (BDA) effort that may touch many areas of molecular biology and engage a wide variety of applications (energy, materials, drug discovery). Early work in BDA may also create valuable DNA assembly and data exchange standards which will help to unify the entire field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of novel living systems for energy, materials, and therapeutics can be greatly accelerated by the creation of software tools and engineering methods. This process is called " bio-design automation" (BDA).BDA is the process of automating the design of novel living systems by using specification, design, assembly, and testing techniques adapted from areas such as computer engineering. This award provided for the development of a "business model canvas" and "customer discovery" for BDA based commercialization opportunities. Team members shared the results of this process with other early stage entrepreneurs and mentors to get feedback and refine their commercialization process.

As a result of this award, over 100 potential BDA customers were interviewed. This included academics, commercial firms, and research laboratories. The learnings were captured in a business model canvas which detailed key partners, key activities, value propositions, customer relationships, key resources, customer channels, customer segments, revenue streams, and cost structure. This was used to evaluate the commercial viability of approaches that focus on design software for high throughput DNA cloning techniques. This award led to the development of Lattice Automation Inc. which has succesfully entered into development and consulting deals with commercial partners. Lattice has also successfully completed an NSF SBIR Phase I award as well.

The broader impacts include laying the foundation for a new commercial sector in biotechnology. This includes enabled and enabling technologies as well as shaping the balance between in-house and external BDA development best practices.


Last Modified: 02/07/2017
Modified by: Douglas Densmore
